inveni portum lxxxvi at home lxxxvii last of god save king lxxxviii yankeee doodle come to town lxxxix colonel without regiment xc in fight run away xci satis pugnae xcii under vine fig tree virginian chapter in one of virginian visit home on library wall of one of most famous writer of america there hang two crossed sword relative wore in great war of independence one sword be gallantly drawn in service of king other be weapon of brave honoured republican soldier possessor of harmless trophy have earned for name alike honoured in ancestor country own where genius such a have always peaceful welcome ensuing history reminds of yonder sword in historian study at boston in revolutionary war subject of story native of america child of old dominion found engaged on different side in quarrel coming together peaceably at conclusion a brother must love ever having materially diminished however angrily contest divided colonel in scarlet general in blue buff hang side by side in wainscoted parlour of warringtons in england where descendant of one of brother have shown portrait to with many of letter wrote book paper belonged to in warrington family to distinguish from other personage of respectable race effigy have always gone by name of virginian by name memoir be christened of passed much time in europe lived just on verge of old world from be drifting away so swiftly be familiar with many variety of men fortune lot brought into contact with personage of whom read only in book who seem alive a read in virginian letter regarding whose voice almost fancy hear a read yellow page written score of year since blotted with boyish tear of disappointed passion dutifully despatched after famous ball ceremony of grand old world scribbled by camp fire out of prison nay there be one have bullet through of greater portion of text be blotted out with blood of bearer letter have probably never be preserved for affectionate thrift of one person to whom never failed in dutiful correspondence mother kept son letter from very first in henry younger of twin sends love to brother then ill of sprain at grandfather house of castlewood in virginia thanks grandpapa for horse ride with tutor down to last from beloved son reached few hour before death venerable lady never visited europe save once with parent in reign of george second took refuge in richmond when house of castlewood be burned down during war be called madam esmond ever after event never caring much for name family of warrington held in very slight estimation a compared to own letter of virginian a reader will presently see from specimen to be shown to be by mean full be hint rather than description indication outline chiefly may be that present writer have mistaken form filled in colour wrongly poring over document have tried to imagine situation of writer where be by what person surrounded have drawn figure a fancied be set down conversation a think might have heard so to best of ability endeavoured to revivify bygone time people with what success task have be accomplished with what profit amusement to kind reader will please to determine one summer morning in year in reign of majesty king george second young rachel virginian ship edward frank master came up avon river on happy return from annual voyage to potomac proceeded to bristol with tide moored in stream a near a possible to trail wharf to be consigned mr trail part owner who must survey ship from counting house window straightway took boat came up side owner of young rachel large grave man in own hair of demure aspect gave hand of welcome to captain frank who stood on deck congratulated captain upon speedy fortunate voyage have made remarking that ought to be thankful to heaven for mercy proceeded presently to business by asking particular relative to cargo passenger frank be pleasant man who loved joke have say yonder ugly negro boy who be fetching trunk passenger who have state cabin to mr trail looked a if must have preferred more mercy from heaven confound frank luck duke william came in last week brought fourteen be not half of tonnage passenger who have whole cabin pay nothin ' continued captain swear now will do good mr trail indeed will have tried medicine passenger take whole cabin not pay gracious mercy be fool captain frank ask passenger for here come a master spoke young man of nineteen year of age came up hatchway have cloak sword under arm be dressed in deep mourning called out gumbo idiot why fetch baggage out of cabin well shipmate journey be ended will see little folk to night whom have be talking about give love to polly betty little tommy not forgetting duty to mr frank thought yesterday voyage must never be done now be almost sorry be over little berth in cabin look very comfortable now be going to leave mr trail scowled at young passenger who have paid money for passage scarcely nodded head to stranger when captain frank said here gentleman be mr trail sir whose name have heerd of be pretty well known in bristol sir say mr trail majestically be mr warrington madam esmond warrington son of castlewood continued captain british merchant hat be instantly off head owner of beaver be making prodigious number of bow a if crown prince be before gracious power mr warrington be delight indeed what crowning mercy that voyage must have be so prosperous must have boat to go on shore let cordially respectfully welcome to england let shake hand a son of benefactress patroness mr esmond warrington whose name be known honoured on bristol 'change warrant be frank there sir horrible be fine young man very picture of one only hair be black be now hanging in bloody indian wigwam be often often on board of young rachel must have chest of book broke open on deck before be landed be shy silent young gent not like one be merriest wildest young fellow full of song fun took on dreadful at news went to bed have that fever lay so many of 'em by heel along swampy potomac object of compassion mr trail assumed lugubrious countenance befitting tragic compliment with prepared to greet young virginian latter answered very curtly declined offer of hospitality only stayed in mr trail house long enough to drink glass of wine to take up sum of money of stood in need captain frank parted on very warmest term little crew of young rachel cheered from ship side a passenger left again again harry warrington brother have pored over english map determined upon course must take upon arriving at home american who love old country what gently nurtured man woman of anglo saxon race doe not have ere rehearsed english travel visited in fancy spot with hope parent fond story friend description have rendered familiar there be few thing to more affecting in history of quarrel divided two great nation than recurrence of word home a used by younger towards elder country harry warrington have chart laid out before london glorious temple of st paul st peter grim tower where brave loyal have shed blood from wallace down to balmerino kilmarnock pitied by gentle heart before awful window of whitehall whence martyr charles have issued to kneel once more then ascend to heaven before playhouse park palace wondrous resort of wit pleasure splendour before shakspeare resting place under tall spire rise by avon amidst sweet warwickshire pasture before derby falkirk culloden where cause of honour loyalty have fallen might be to rise more before point of pilgrimage there be one young virginian brother held even more sacred be home of family that old castlewood in hampshire about parent have talked so fondly from bristol to bath from bath to salisbury to winchester to hexton to home knew way have mapped journey many many time must fancy american traveller to be handsome young fellow whose suit of sable only made look more interesting plump landlady from bar surrounded by china punch bowl stout gilded bottle of strong water glittering row of silver flagon looked kindly after young gentleman a passed through inn hall from post chaise obsequious chamberlain bowed upstairs to rose dolphin trim chambermaid dropped best curtsey for fee gumbo in inn kitchen where townsfolk drank mug of ale by great fire bragged of young master splendid house in virginia of immense wealth to be heir postchaise whirled traveller through most delightful home scenery eye have ever lighted on if english landscape be pleasant to american of present day who must need contrast rich wood glowing pasture picturesque ancient village of old country with rough aspect of own how much pleasanter must harry warrington course have be whose journey have lain through swamp forest solitude from one virginian ordinary to log house at end of day route who now lighted suddenly upon busy happy splendid scene of english summer highroad hundred year ago be not that grass grown desert of present time be alive with constant travel traffic country town inn swarmed with life gaiety ponderous waggon with bell plodding team light post coach achieved journey from white hart salisbury to swan with two neck london in two day string of packhorse have not yet left road lord gilt postchaise six with outrider galloping on ahead country squire great coach heavy flanders mare farmer trotting to market parson jolting to cathedral town on dumpling wife behind on pillion crowding sight brisk people greeted young traveller on summer journey hodge farmer boy took off hat polly milkmaid bobbed curtsey a chaise whirled over pleasant village green white headed child lifted chubby face cheered church spire glistened with gold cottage gable glared in sunshine great elm murmured in summer cast purple shadow over grass young warrington never have such glorious day witnessed scene so delightful to be nineteen year of age with high health high spirit full purse to be making first journey rolling through country in postchaise at nine mile hour o happy youth almost make one young to think of harry be too eager to give more than passing glance at abbey at bath gaze with more than moment wonder at mighty minster at salisbury until beheld home seemed to have eye for other place at last young gentleman postchaise drew up at rustic inn on castlewood green of grandsire have many time talked to bear a ensign swinging from elm near inn porch three castle of esmond family have sign too over gateway of castlewood house bearing same cognisance be hatchment of francis lord castlewood who now lay in chapel hard by son reigning in stead harry warrington have often heard of francis lord castlewood be for frank sake for great love towards boy colonel esmond determined to forgo claim to english estate rank of family retired to virginia young man have led wild youth have fought with distinction under marlborough have married foreign lady most lamentably adopted religion at one time have be jacobite for loyalty to sovereign be ever hereditary in esmond family have received slight injury from prince have caused to rally to king george side have on second marriage renounced error of popery have temporarily embraced returned to established church again have from constant support of king minister of time being be rewarded by majesty george ii died english peer earl coronet now figured on hatchment hung over castlewood gate there be end of jolly gentleman between colonel esmond who have become stepfather lordship there have ever be brief affectionate correspondence on colonel part especially who loved stepson have hundred story to tell about to a did castlewood act of revolt be a selfish a rest of family not so mean a candidly stated must afford luxury of little independence having tolerable estate to fall back upon madam bernstein be early woman restless resolute extraordinarily active for age be up long before languid castlewood lady just home from london rout ball have quitted feather bed jolly will have slept off various potation of innocence happiness did calm beauty soothe please awaken remorse in heart manner be more than ordinarily affectionate gentle when presently after pacing walk for half hour person for whom be waiting came to be young virginian to whom have despatched early billet by one of lockwoods note be signed b bernstein informed mr esmond warrington that relative at castlewood among dear friend of grandfather be most anxious that must come to colonel esmond house in england now accordingly lad made appearance passing under old gothic doorway tripping down step from one garden terrace to hat in esmond daughter grandson be born wife died lady when married be widow of colonel kinsman unlucky viscount castlewood killed in duel by lord mohun at close of king william reign mr esmond called money getting roundhead of pennsylvania new england never be people le republican than of great province be soon to be foremost in memorable revolt against british crown gentry of virginia dwelt on great land after fashion almost patriarchal for rough cultivation estate have multitude of hand of purchased assigned servant who be subject to command of master land yielded food live stock game great river swarmed with fish for taking from bank passage home be clear ship took tobacco off private wharf on bank of potomac james river carried to london bristol bringing back english good article of home manufacture in return for only produce virginian gentry chose to cultivate hospitality be boundless stranger be ever sent away from gate gentry received one travelled to other house in state almost feudal question of slavery be not born at time of write to be proprietor of black servant shocked feeling of virginian gentleman in truth be despotism exercised over negro race generally savage one food be plenty poor black people lazy not unhappy might have preached negro emancipation to madam esmond of castlewood a might have told to let horse run loose out of stable have doubt that whip corn bag be good for father may have thought otherwise being of sceptical turn on very many point doubt did not break forth in active denial be rather disaffected than rebellious at one period gentleman have taken part in active life at home possibly might have be eager to share reward in latter day did not seem to care for something have occurred in life have cast tinge of melancholy over existence be not unhappy to about most kind most affectionate obsequious even to woman of family whom be scarce ever contradicted there have be bankruptcy of heart spirit never recovered submitted to life rather than enjoyed never be in better spirit than in last hour when be going to lay down having lost wife daughter took management of colonel affair gave up to charge with entire acquiescence so that have book quiet cared for more when company came to castlewood entertained handsomely be of very pleasant sarcastical turn be not in least sorry when went away love will not be sorry to go said to george now began to give way to wicked sarcastic method perhaps have inherited from grandfather with when quiet skilful young person chooses to employ can make whole family uncomfortable took up ward pompous remark made joke of so that young divine chafed almost choked over great meal made madam esmond angry doubly so when sent off harry into fit of laughter authority be defied officer litigant company called ohio company having grant from virginia government of land along river found invaded in settlement by french military detachment who roughly ejected briton from holding latter applied for protection to mr dinwiddie lieutenant governor of virginia who determined upon sending ambassador to french commanding officer on ohio demanding that french must desist from inroad upon territory of majesty king george young mr washington jumped eagerly at chance of distinction service afforded volunteered to leave home rural professional pursuit in virginia to carry governor message to french officer taking guide interpreter few attendant following indian track in fall of year intrepid young envoy made way from williamsburg almost to shore of lake erie found french commander at affectionate george e warrington whole land be now lying parched scorching in july heat for ten day news have come from column advancing on ohio march though toiled slowly through painful forest must bring ere long up with enemy troop led by consummate captain be accustomed now to wilderness not afraid of surprise precaution have be taken against ambush be outlying enemy who be discovered pursued destroyed by vigilant scout skirmisher of british force last news heard be that army have advanced considerably beyond ground of mr washington discomfiture on previous year two day after must be within day march of french fort about taking fear be entertained amount of french reinforcement from montreal be known mr braddock with two veteran regiment from britain ally of virginia pennsylvania through have be allowed to go entirely free so george have given up favourite mare like hero a be be marching afoot with line madam esmond vowed that must have best horse in virginia carolina in place of roxana there be horse enough to be have in province for money be only for king service that be not forthcoming although at family meeting repast inmate of castlewood always talked cheerfully never anticipating triumphant issue to campaign acknowledging feeling of disquiet must be owned be mighty uneasy when at home quitting ceaselessly for ever on trot from one neighbour house to in quest of news be prodigious how quickly report ran spread when for instance certain noted border warrior called colonel jack have offered huntsman to general who have declined ruffian term proffered service defection of jack men be talk of thousand of tongue immediately house negro in midnight gallop about country in search of junketing sweetheart brought spread news over amazingly wide district have curious knowledge of incident of march for fortnight at least after commencement knew laughed at cheat practised on army for horse provision like for good bargain over foreigner be not unfrequent unpleasant practice among new yorkers pennsylvanian marylander though 't be known that american folk have become perfectly artless simple in later time never grasp never overreach be never selfish now for three week after army departure thousand report regarding be cheerful when castlewood friend met at supper tone be confident news pleasant on th of july vast sudden gloom spread over province look of terror doubt seemed to fall upon face affrighted negro wistfully eyed master retired hummed whispered with one fiddle ceased in quarter song laugh of cheery black folk be hushed right left everybody servant be on gallop for news country tavern be thronged with horseman who drank cursed brawled at bar bringing gloomy story army have be surprised troop have fallen into ambuscade have be cut up almost to man officer be taken down by french marksman savage general have be wounded carried off field in sash four day afterwards report be that general be dead scalped by french indian ah what scream poor mr mountain gave when gumbo brought news from across james river little fanny sprang cry to mother arm lord god almighty watch over defend boy said mr esmond sinking down on knee lifting rigid hand to heaven gentleman be not at home when rumour arrived came in hour two afterwards from hunt for news scot tutor did not dare to look up meet widow agonising look harry warrington be a pale a mother might not be true about manner of general death be dead army have be surprised by indian have fled be killed without seeing enemy express have arrived from dunbar camp fugitive be pouring in there must go see must go see stout little dempster armed mounted taking couple of mounted servant with followed northward track expeditionary army have hewed out for at step brought nearer expedition have shown utmost bravery resolution four time horse have be shot under twice have be wounded last time of mortal hurt ended life three day after battle more than one of harry informant be at bromley two minute within hour new horse kep going at capital rate drove having postilion by to show way black man inside with mr betty hope found drive very pleasant be not stopped on blackheath though two fellow on horseback rode up to not liking look of countenantses rode off again got into tunbridge well where transacted business at forty five minute after eleven make quitts with lordship after yesterday piquet will be very happy to give revenge be most obliged faithful servant h esmond warrington now perhaps reader will understand by what mean lady maria esmond be enabled to surprise dear aunt in bed on saturday morning walk out of house of captivity having despatched mr betty to london scarcely expected that emissary must return on day of departure chaplain be playing card at midnight after small refection bailiff wife have provided for when rapid whirling of wheel be heard approaching house caused lady to lay trump down heart to beat with more than ordinary emotion whirr came wheel carriage stopped at very door there be parley at gate then appeared mr betty with face radiant with joy though eye be full of tear next who be that tall young gentleman who enters can of reader guess will be very angry if say that chaplain slapped down card with huzzay whilst lady maria turning a white a sheet rose up from chair tottered forward step two with hysterical shriek flung in cousin arm how many kiss did give if be mille deinde centum dein mille altera dein secunda centum so on be not going to cry out have come to rescue knew must be pocket humbly asked if patron have have bad night have be brought home from white by two chairman at five o'clock in morning have caught confounded cold for one of window of chair must not shut rain snow came in finally be in such bad humour that poor sampson quirk joke must scarcely extort smile from at last to be sure mr warrington burst into loud laugh be when poor chaplain after sufficient discussion of muffin egg tea news theatre so forth pulled paper out of pocket in piteous tone said here be that schedule of debt honour asked for two hundred forty three pound shilling owe in world wicked look burst into laugh be however anything jovial wicked execration moreover accompanied outbreak of humour luckless chaplain felt that petition have come at wrong moment confound why did bring on monday harry asked confound why did not bring on monday echoed chaplain timid soul be luck usual luck have card be against mr warrington yes plague on monday night last night have gone against be off mackreth in counter last night must pay at dinner time will do business for nevertheless never fear good mr sampson come to breakfast to morrow will see deliver reverence from philistine though naughty word showed did not relieve agitation of spirit in mood young fellow be interrupted by appearance of friend who on other day even on one when conscience be so uneasy be welcome to mr warrington be other than mr lambert in military dress with cloak over who have come from country have be to captain general levee that morning have come thence to visit young friend in bond street howe hoisting broad pennant on board success frigate went in a near a possible to shore followed by other frigate to protect landing of troop now with lord george sackville general dury in command whither frequently though privately came for guidance comfort that seemed to that child be right in persistent fidelity to wrong in demanding utter submission hence jack cause be won almost before began to plead brave gentle heart must bear rancour bled at inflicting pain on loved even shrank from asserting authority demanding submission be only too glad to return to natural pulse of love affection chapter lxxviii pyramus thisbe in examining old paper at home year afterwards found docketed labelled with mother well known neat handwriting from london april son dreadful letter when came to be mine burnt document not choosing that story of domestic grief disunion must remain amongst family annals for future warringtons to gaze on mayhap disobedient son to hold up a example of foregone domestic rebellion for similar reason have destroyed paper mother despatched to at time of tyranny revolt annoyance irritation maddened by pang of separation from mistress not unrightly considering that mr esmond be prime cause of greatest grief misery have ever befallen in world wrote home to virginia letter might have be more temperate be true in endeavoured to maintain extremest respect reticence said did not know by what motif have be influenced that held answerable for misery of future life have chosen wilfully to mar render wretched have occasioned separation between virtuous innocent young creature whose own hope health happiness be cast down for ever by mr esmond interference deed be done a feared must offer comment upon conduct of perpetrator who be answerable to god alone did not disguise from mother that injury have done be so dreadful mortal that life mine must never repair that tie of allegiance be broken towards never must be a heretofore dutiful respectful son madam esmond replied to in letter of very great dignity style correspondence be extraordinarily elegant fine uttered not single reproach hard word coldly gave to understand that be before awful tribunal of god have referred case between asked for counsel that in respect of own conduct a mother be ready in humility to face might a son be equally able to answer for to show when great judge demanded question of whether have done own duty honoured father mother o popoi grandfather have quoted in memoir line of homer showing how in trouble grief god be always called in question when pride avarice interest desire to domineer be worked upon be not for ever pestering heaven to decide in favour in great american quarrel did not on side appeal to sky a to justice of cause sing te deum for victory boldly express confidence that right must prevail be america right because be victorious then suppose poland be wrong because be defeated how be wandering into digression about poland america fallen upon in consequence of remissness selfishness rapacity of many of very people for whose defence against french arm have be taken up colonist be for having done for for doing nothing made occurred for ill will what shout of joy be there what ovation for great british minister who have devised effected conquest of canada monsieur de vaudreuil said justly that conquest be signal for defection of north american colony from allegiance to great britain lord chatham having done best to achieve first part of scheme contributed more than man in england towards completion of colony be insurgent applauded rebellion what score of thousand of waverer must have encouraged into resistance be general who say to army in revolt god save king men have right to mutiny wonder set up statue in matter in dispute who have not in troublesome time argument be carried on without rancour even new sister must not bring to though did best when be together in curtain lecture have doubt inflicted on spouse like notable housewife a be trusted in other so entirely that even harry duty towards wife must not make quarrel with brother loved from old time when word be law with still protested that virginian gentleman of side be loyal to crown war be not declared a yet gentleman of different opinion be courteous enough to one nay at public dinner festival health of king be still ostentatiously drunk assembly of colony though preparing for congress though resisting attempt at taxation on part of home authority be loud in expression of regard for king father pathetic in appeal to paternal sovereign to put away evil counsellor from listen to voice of moderation reason up to last virginian gentry be grave orderly aristocratic folk with strongest sense of own dignity station in later day nearer home have heard of fraternisation equality amongst great folk of old world have never seen gentleman standing more on dignity maintaining better than mr washington not king against whom took arm in eye of gentry of french court who gaily joined in crusade against so took revenge for canada great american chief always appeared a anax andron allowed that better must not be seen in versailles though be quarrelling with governor gentleman of house of burgess still maintained amicable relation with exchanged dignified courtesy when lord bottetourt arrived held court at williamsburg in small splendour state gentry waited upon madam esmond included at death lord dunmore who succeeded brought fine family with be treated with utmost respect by gentry privately though publicly house of assembly governor be at war quarrel be matter of history concern personally only so far a that burgess being convened for st of march in year after arrival in virginia be agreed that must pay visit to capital duty to governor since harry unfortunate marriage madam esmond have not performed duty though always previously accustomed to pay now that eldest son be arrived in colony mother opined that must certainly wait upon excellency governor be sorry perhaps to get away from little richmond to enjoy gaiety of provincial capital madam engaged at great price best house to be have at richmond for herself family now be rich generosity be curious have more than once to interpose old servant likewise wondering at new way of life beg not to be so lavish gently said in former in open hostility in maryland pennsylvania flattered that much more loyal spirit be prevalent in carolina georgia mother country must reckon upon staunch adherent great majority of inhabitant never be be only eager for moment when might draw sword scatter rascally rebel before of course in meeting be forced to hear many hard word against poor harry wife agreed not without good reason perhaps have led to adopt extreme anti british opinion have of late declared be infatuated by attachment to gentleman of mount vernon be farther said whose opinion brother always followed who day by day be committing farther in dreadful desperate course of resistance be friend people about excellency said be man favoured who have have special confidence who have repeatedly shared hospitality must not be owned much of be true though what of eager loyalist called treachery be indeed rather proof of longing desire mr washington other gentleman have not to withdraw from allegiance to crown to remain faithful exhaust very last chance of reconciliation before risked other terrible alternative of revolt separation let traitor arm villain draw parricidal sword at least must remain faithful unconquerable power of england must be exerted misguided ungrateful province punished brought back to obedience with what cheer drank majesty health after banquet must die in defence of right must have prince of royal house to come govern ancient dominion in consideration of own excellent mother loyalty brother benighted conduct must be forgiven be yet too late to secure by offering good command must not intercede with who be known have great influence over in williamsburg council be alternately in state of exaltation triumph of hope of fury against rebel of anxious expectancy of home succour of doubt distrust gloom promised to intercede with brother wrote to own with little hope of success repeating trying to strengthen argument have many time used in conversation mother too used authority from own expected little advantage assailed a habit be with such text of scripture a thought bore out own opinion threatened punishment to menaced with penalty must fall upon who be disobedient to power be pointed to elder brother example hinted fear at subjection to wife very worst argument must use in such controversy did not show own letter to possibly knew might find fault with energy of of expression thought proper to employ showed answer from gathered what style tenor of argument have be if madam esmond brought scripture to aid mr hal to surprise brought score of text to bear upon in reply addressed in very neat temperate even elegant composition thought wife be scarcely capable of penning indeed found have enlisted service of mr belman new richmond clergyman who have taken up strong opinion on whig side who preached printed sermon against hagan who a have said be of faction in fear belman have best of dispute exhortation to hal have more success than mother did not answer letter being still farther pressed by friend of government wrote over most imprudently to say must visit at end of week at fanny mount on arriving only found sister who received with perfect cordiality informed that hal be gone into country ever so far towards blue mountain to look at horse be to be away did not know how long be to be away knew then there be hope dear said a far a whole of american war slaughter inflicted upon from behind line be so severe behaviour of enemy so resolute that british chief respected barricade of american hereafter be firing from behind row of blanket certain of general rather hesitated to force in affair of white plain when for second time mr washington army be quite at mercy of victor subsequently heard that conquering troop be held back before barricade actually composed of cornstalk straw opportunity be given lasted during whole winter during dwindling dismayed troop of congress lay starving unarmed under grasp magnanimous mr howe left famous camp of valley forge untouched whilst great brave perfectly appointed army fiddled gambled feasted in philadelphia by byng countryman triumphal arch be erected tournament be held in pleasant mockery of middle age wreath garland offered by beautiful lady to clement chief with fantastical motto posy announcing that laurel must be immortal why have ungrateful countryman in america never erected statue to general have not in army officer who fought battle better who enabled to retrieve error with such adroitness who took care that defeat must be so little hurtful to when in course of event stronger force naturally got uppermost who showed untiring tenderness patience complacency in helping poor disabled opponent on to leg again ah think of eighteen year before fiery young warrior whom england have sent out to fight adversary on american continent fancy for ever pacing round defence behind foe lie sheltered by night by day alike sleepless eager consuming away in fierce wrath longing never closing eye so intent be in watching winding track with untiring scent that pant hunger for blood battle prowling through midnight forest climbing silent over precipice before dawn watching till great heart be almost worn out until foe show at last when spring on grapple with dying slays think of wolfe at quebec hearken to howe fiddle a sits smiling amongst dancer at philadelphia favourite scheme with minister at home of general in america be to establish communication between canada new york by mean be hoped new england might be cut off from neighbouring colony overpowered in detail forced into submission burgoyne be entrusted with conduct of plan set forth from quebec confidently promising to bring to successful issue march began in military state trumpet of proclamation blew before bade colonist to remember immense power of england summoned misguided rebel to lay down arm brought with formidable english force army of german veteran not le powerful dreadful band of indian warrior brilliant train of artillery be supposed that people round march must rally to royal cause standard continental force in front of be small at first washington army be albany then be time when washington weakened army must have be struck too greater power willed otherwise be for one even going to regret termination of war a look over game now how clear seem blunder occasion if common report said true subsequently married rendered miserable lady of title fortune in england poor little american lady interested union with lord castlewood be scarcely more happy captain charles esmond have resigned commission in majesty service a not wishing to take up arm against countryman of mother countess of castlewood be doing of old fox van den bosch madam esmond said wish to keep virginian property safe side must win may mention with respect to old worthy that continued to reside in england for while after declaration of independence not at denying sympathy with american cause keeping pretty quiet tongue alleging that very old man a be past age of action mischief in opinion government concurred doubt a be left quite unmolested of sudden warrant be out after when be surprising with what agility stirred skipped off to france whence presently embarked upon return to virginia old man bore worst reputation amongst loyalist of colony be nicknamed jack painter amongst much to indignation after certain miscreant who be hung in england for burning naval store in port there professed to have lost prodigious sum at home by persecution of government
